bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Bertha L. Lyons, April 20, 1948

div1.p: Hench assures Lyons that he meant to put no pressure on her to include Reed's Congressional Medal in the Hall of Fame exhibit.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Bertha L. Lyons, April 20, 1948
div1.opener:
April 20, 1948
Miss Bertha L. Lyons
Assistant to the Director
Hall of Fame, New York University
1 Madison Avenue
New York 10, New York
My dear Miss Lyons:
div1.p:
Thank you very kindly for your letter of April 14. I certainly
will appreciate receiving 50 copies of the program if this is not too
much trouble.

As to the Congressional Medal, please do not allow me to put
any pressure upon you. I didn't mean to do so. It is simply that I
have a very high regard for anybody who gets a Congressional Medal, the
highest military honor that our government can bestow. Since you haven't
planned to put it in let it go at that. It is your program, you are
planning it and I do not wish to interfere in any way.

I shall be on hand for the affair and at the moment, I think that
I shall come by train and sleep the whole way! I will arrive Thursday, May 20.

You mention a procession. Does that involve the wearing of an
academic gown? If so, I have my own and can bring it. I have represented
one of my alma maters at several college presidential inaugurations and have
gotten so that an academic gown seems about as habitual as evening clothes
but certainly I don't want to bring it unless it is necessary.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
